_exec_summary.SummaryText:
Schreiber Foods, Inc. (SFI) is a global enterprise and the worlds largest privately held cheese processor. SFI is

the nations largest supplier of store-brand cheese products to grocery chains and wholesalers. SFI operates

numerous manufacturing/processing facilities throughout the U.S. The SFI Richland Center East Plant employs

approximately 304 people. The SFI plant uses anhydrous ammonia for refrigeration of the products in storage

as well as for cooling of manufacturing process lines. Anhydrous ammonia is subject to EPA regulation under

40 CFR 68, Accidental Release Risk Management of Highly Hazardous Chemicals.

Pursuant to the RMP regulations (40 CFR 68) and the Process Safety Management (PSM) regulations, SFI has

developed a comprehensive PSM written program to protect our employees and the surrounding community

from exposure to the hazardous chemicals onsite. The facility completed an initial process hazards analysis

(PHA) for ammonia using a HAZOP Analysis. The original PHA was completed using technical and

operations staff from the Richland Center East Plant as well as experienced facilitators. The PHA reviewed operational,

human factors, and facility siting issues relative to the design of the refrigeration system, and

recommendations were made, as appropriate, to address these concerns.

SFI's implementation of the PSM program includes employee education in the hazards of ammonia and

measures that can be used to reduce employee and community exposure to accidental releases of ammonia.

The plans include preventive maintenance programs (mechanical integrity) for the ammonia system, and a

program for both pre-startup safety reviews and management of changes (MOC) to the system. The program

also includes specific requirements for safe work practices (such as safe approaches to welding and similar

hot work) and safety requirements for contractors who may be hired to work on the system. Finally, SFI has

undertaken a rigorous approach to PSM com

pliance auditing. Findings from the audits are reported to the

facility, which then must correct the findings and provide written documentation of resolution of the findings

to SFI's Safety Director.



Lastly, the PSM written program incorporates the Plant's Emergency Response Plan and places special

emphasis on handling accidental releases of hazardous chemicals and coordination of emergency response

with local fire departments and other emergency response organizations. Many of SFI's refrigeration and

maintenance personnel have completed 24-hour HAZWOPER HAZMAT technician level training program.

This training emphad topics such as classification systems and hazards identification; ammonia spill

control and containment; respiratory protection; air monitoring instrumentation; proper personal protective

equipment; medical monitoring; and proper termination procedures for emergency response activities. The

facility conducts annual HAZWOPER refresher training to keep employees current and comfortable with their

responsibilities under the plan using classroom discussion and response to mock emergency scenarios. The

facility also conducts drills during which the emergency response team practices implementation of the

incident command system to respond to mock emergency situations.

As part of the RMP requirements, SFI undertook a review of the potential offsite consequences of the

accidental release of the largest vessel in the systems. Although such a release is highly unlikely, the

regulation requires this review. The following describes the results of the analysis.



Ammonia Refrigeration

SFI stores and uses anhydrous ammonia on site for refrigeration of products in storage as well as for cooling

of manufacturing process lines. Ammonia is used for its excellent energy efficiency and flexibility, in addition

to benefits to employee safety. Ammonia at the facility is kept entirely within the refrigeration system, much

as the refrigerant in your car a

ir-conditioner. SFI is committed to minimizing accidental releases of ammonia from the refrigeration process at the SFI - Richland Center East Plant. Facility management is involved in the design, operation, and maintenance of the system. SFI employees at all levels have been involved in the development of the PSM and RMP programs. Management

has committed to working with local agencies and the community to educate the public regarding the

hazards of ammonia and to ensure a safe workplace and surrounding community.
